results.title: Faces
results.brief_description: “Faces” concentrates on two scenarios, one where middle-aged businessmen cheat on their wives and the other where the wives bring home a younger man from a nightclub. Both wives and husbands take turns in testing the novelty of the situations, initially improvising to bridge the awkwardness but then risking more and more. While the night out feels liberating, it ends up tearing painfully at their conservative personas.

results.title: Shadows
results.brief_description:
‘Shadows’ was a vanguard work of the independent American cinema, a bittersweet comedy centred on three African-American outsiders - Lelia and his two jazz-musicians brothers living in Greenwich Village - two of whom pass for white and all are part of the late fifties ‘lost generation’. We follow Lelia through three brief romantic involvements. Although the film was recognised at the time for its treatment of race, Cassavetes saw this as incidental to the wider question of identity. His special commitment to expression through performance and a concomitant openness of form give his films a rough, uninflected, anecdotal quality (a form of ‘fictional cinema
verite’). ‘Shadows’, like other Cassavetes’ films was fully scripted despite the reference in the end title to the film as ‘an improvisation’.
Cast includes Lelia Goldoni, Ben Carruthers, Hugh Hurd.

results.title: Hairy tales
results.brief_description:
“Hairy tales” is a group-devised story made by children about a group of children who get lost in the Australian bush and who are finally rescued by a magical emu that shows them the way home.
The work was commissioned and made by a group of children who attended a filmmaking and drama workshop over three weekends at the Artplay Centre in Melbourne - a new children’s contemporary art centre established by the City of Melbourne.
The children developed the narrative using theatrical improvisation techniques taught in the workshop. The visuals were created by compositing live action and animation using a “black screen” technique providing opportunities for either drawn or filmed backgrounds that were added in post-production. The children participating in the workshops created all the content for the film. The film was directed and edited by multimedia artist Michael Buckley and produced for Artplay by creative producer, Sue McCauley.

results.title: Opening night
results.brief_description: Myrtle Gordon is a successful actress who finds the part she has taken in a new play, about a “defeated, older woman”, humiliating. When a young fan is killed outside the theatre one night, Myrtle uses the experience of the girl and the accident to revisit her youth. While she searches for a vantage-point to perform the part, the film shows how the play and the world behind the play interact and threaten to draw her into collapse. Also available on VHS [310942].

results.title: The Happy prince
results.brief_description:
Based on an abridged version of the well-known story of “The Happy prince” by Irish writer Oscar Wilde. It tells of the efforts of a statue, the Happy Prince, to bring relief from poverty to the people in his town with the assistance of a dedicated swallow.
This digital video was made with a class of grade 6 students in a small village school in Dromohaire, County Leitrim, Ireland in late 2003-2004, and directed and edited by Michael Buckley. Sue McCauley was creative producer.
The production combined fine art practices and theatrical improvisation with digital media. The whole work was shot in the classroom at the school with backgrounds and animation added through compositing technique to create a visual richness through multi-layering of the imagery. The vision for the project was to make a work for an audience of children, primarily by children using a theatrical, ensemble, improvisational technique. Funded by the Australian Council for the Arts.

results.title: Killing of a Chinese bookie
results.brief_description: “The Killing of a Chinese Bookie” presents a portrait of a man who is so self-sufficient that he cannot become personally involved with anyone. Cosmo Vitelli, played by Ben Gazzara, is a nightclub owner who believes in conducting his personal and business affairs with plenty of flair and professionalism. When the mob threatens him he works desperately to save his face and the club.

results.title: Twelve tuff tales
results.brief_description:
Twelve students from Grade 6 at Carlton Primary School create their own individual story about a “bad day” from their own perspective. Some examples of the stories include getting chased by snarling dogs in the park, falling over and ruining a new pair of jeans, losing a kid sister at the shops and getting lost in Safeways.
The children involved in making this collection of one-minute works were mostly refugee children who live on an inner Melbourne housing estate and speak English as a second language.
“Twelve tuff tales” was created as a school-based multimedia production and funded by an Arts and Culture grant from the City of Melbourne. It was produced at Artplay: the centre for contemporary arts for children.
The stories include:
1. Bandaids by Abir Musa
2. The Horrible day by Dunya Ahmen
3. Bullies at the park by Hashem Alhassan
4. Lost by Hodan Yusuf
5. Feeding the fishes by JD Bautista
6. Blown away by Meriam Abubeker
7. Untitled - no credits
8. Two big dogs with sharp teeth by Mustafa Housain
9. Untitled - no credits
10. The Shower by Sadam Ahmed
11. Grounded by Thao Le
12. Lost in High Point by Shukri Ismail

results.title: Frankenchicken (series pilot)
results.creator_credit: Ann-Marie Denham, Tom Wild and BigKidz Entertainment
results.brief_description:
As the country’s most famous and prolific fast food company, Crispy Aussie Chook (CAC) maintains the highest quality standards that its customers deserve. Unfortunately, their customers don’t realise that they deserve tainted, genetically modified, and altogether non-chicken material in their “Fun Fried Fancy” packs. As part of their new marketing strategy, CAC is seeking a mascot that epitomises the essence of their company: country fresh, with just a ‘touch’ of enhancement. One willing dupe has come forth, little realising just what is in store. The thing is, neither does CAC. Their latest money-saver in using barmy British bovine in their “Cheeky Chook Chunks” is about to hit a small, but very effective bump in the road.
Witty animated cartoon produced as a possible series pilot.
Animators - Adam parton, Kelly Lynagh, JC Reyes, Ann-Marie Denham, Adam Duncan. Music - Jaedyn Conley.

results.title: Small ant syndrome
results.brief_description: Delightful animated story with warmth and humour about one-up-manship in the microcosmic world of ants. Simplistic in its presentation but fascinating to watch. Sound effects with music soundtrack - music by David Jaedyn Conley.

results.title: Rock et man
results.creator_credit: Adrian Van de Velde, Leone Knight and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
The allegedly true story of Darwin Edward Cole, a serial killer on death row, who claims to have deflected Tesla’s Comet from its intersection with the earth’s orbit, thereby saving the world from certain destruction. He also claims to have returned with a new virus that only kills “deviants”, thus ridding the world of another plague.
He confesses to the murders and insists that he is sane, refusing all attempts to have himself declared unfit to plead.
